newsitem.title: USA: AMD sees K6 shipping in Q2.
newsitem.headline: AMD sees K6 shipping in Q2.

text.p: Advanced Micro Devices Inc is on target to begin shipping its K6 microprocessor in the second quarter and expects initial shipments of "hundreds of thousands of units," a company executive said on Wednesday.

The executive, AMD vice president of external affairs Ben Anixter, also said he expects K6 pricing will be about 25 percent lower than Intel Corp's Pentium Pro chip. The K6 is compatible with the Pentium Pro technology.
Anixter, who was speaking at a Goldman Sachs technology conference, said AMD will market the chip as being "designed for Windows 95," Microsoft Corp's operating system.
He declined to name potential customers for the chip.
"The interest for this product is very high," he said. "It's not our policy to say whether we have orders."

Anixter said AMD is building enough capacity to target a 30 percent microprocessor market share -- roughly 30 million units in 1998 -- although he said the company's goal is for a 20-25 percent market share by then.
